title.native: 鬼滅の刃 刀鍛冶の里編
title.romaji: Kimetsu no Yaiba: Katanakaji no Sato-hen
title.english: Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba Swordsmith Village Arc

description:
Adaptation of the Swordsmith Village Arc.

Tanjiro’s journey leads him to the Swordsmith Village, where he reunites with two Hashira, members of the Demon Slayer Corps’ highest-ranking swordsmen - Mist Hashira Muichiro Tokito and Love Hashira Mitsuri Kanroji. With the shadows of demons lurking near, a new battle begins for Tanjiro and his comrades.

Notes:
• The first episode has a runtime of ~49 minutes, and received an early premiere in cinemas worldwide as part of a special screening alongside the final two episodes of Kimetsu no Yaiba: Yuukaku-hen.
• The final episode has a runtime of ~52 minutes.
synonyms: ดาบพิฆาตอสูร ภาค 3 บทหมู่บ้านช่างตีดาบ
Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba - Le village des forgerons
Истребитель демонов: Kimetsu no Yaiba. Деревня кузнецов
Miecz zabójcy demonów – Kimetsu no Yaiba: Wioska płatnerzy

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Curses
tags.description: Features a character, object or area that has been cursed, usually by a malevolent supernatural force.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Monster Girl
tags.description: Prominently features a female character who is part-monster.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Clone
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is an artificial exact copy of another organism.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Rural
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the countryside.

tags.name: Orphan
tags.description: Prominently features a character that is an orphan.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Twins
tags.description: Prominently features two or more siblings that were born at one birth.

alternative: てっちかわはらてっちん

node.description: Author of Kimetsu no Yaiba and Haeniwa no Zigzag. On February 2021, Gotouge was selected for the TIME 100 Next list, making it the first time a mangaka appears on the list.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/外崎春雄)

Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/松島晃)

Originating from Jec.E, currently affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).

After graduating from middle school he entered Yoyogi Animation vocational school where he fell in love with animation. He then joined Jec.E, a sub-contracting studio. After it's bankruptcy he went freelance, but had a seat he used for workspace at Studio Elle. In 2010, he joined [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/) and has been one of its key members since, together with animators like [Nozomu Abe](https://anilist.co/staff/116271/), [Masayuki Kunihiro](https://anilist.co/staff/146702/) and [Masaru Kimura](https://anilist.co/staff/146698/). In 2019, he served as the character designer and chief animation director on [Demon Slayer](https://anilist.co/anime/101922/) and the [movie sequel](https://anilist.co/anime/112151/) following it, which became the highest-grossing anime film and Japanese film of all time.

Highly praised for his work as an animation director on [Rurouni Kenshin](https://anilist.co/anime/45/), [Hunter x Hunter](https://anilist.co/anime/136/) and [Naruto](https://anilist.co/anime/20/).

Influenced by the likes of [Tetsuya Nishio](https://anilist.co/staff/103725/) and [Nobuteru Yuuki](https://anilist.co/staff/97010/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/松島晃)

name.native: マン・ウィズ・ア・ミッション

node.description:
[Website](https://www.mwamjapan.info) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/mwamofficial) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/MWAMofficial) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/mwamofficial/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/MWAMjapan)

__Introduction:__
Man with a Mission, stylized as MAN WITH A MISSION or sometimes as MWAM is a Japanese rock band which was formed in Shibuya, Tokyo, Japan in 2010. This band currently consists five band members, with stage names of Tokyo Tanaka, Jean-Ken Johnny, Kamikaze Boy, DJ Santa Monica and Spear Rib.

MWAM's music style has been described as hard rock and dance rock. Their distinguishing feature is that all of the members wear differently designed wolf masks during both their concerts and their music videos. Many of their singles have been used as theme songs for a variety of anime, live-action movies, and video games.

__Biography:__
Before becoming popular, the band invented a back-story for why they wear wolf masks, which involves them being created as the "Ultimate Life Form" by [Jimi Hendrix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimi_Hendrix), who is described by the band as being the doctor of the guitar and master wolf biologist. They were then frozen in Antarctica for years. While they were frozen, they had been listening to all kinds of music from all around the world, before later escaping and emerging onto the Japanese music scene.

The earliest debut of the band was in a number of live gigs at venues in the Shibuya area. The band organized an American tour in late 2010, which was called their "[Whisky a Go Go](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whisky_a_Go_Go)" tour and involved multiple gigs at night clubs in Los Angeles. The tour itself ended in November 2010. The end of their tour coincided with the release of their first mini album, ___Welcome to the New World___, in November as well, which went on to sell out in a number of stores across Japan. The mini album also spent six weeks on the [Oricon Top 100](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oricon) for number of sales. On April 29, 2011, they released a new single titled "Never Fxxkin' Mind the Rules". After the single release, the band started another music tour on March 7, 2011, called "Man with a Mission Japan Marking Tour 2011", which included 13 different performances across Japan. Their first full debut album, ___Man with a Mission___, released on June 8, 2011.

Soon after the release of their album, they participated in a major Japanese concert event, known as "[Summer Sonic 2011](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Summer_Sonic_Festival)" in mid-August, and also a number of other summer festivals, such as "Countdown Japan 11/12". Labeled by ___Eggman Magazine___ as the "Most Promising Newcomer", tickets to their show at the concert festival sold out within ten minutes. During the stream of concerts, their songs were also run on 27 of the major FM and AM radio broadcasting stations nationwide across Japan. On October 5, 2011, the band released an EP titled ___Trick or Treat___, which included a number of original songs and also cover songs, such as "[Smells Like Teen Spirit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smells_Like_Teen_Spirit)" by [Nirvana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nirvana_(band)). The members of Man with a Mission were also featured in a poster campaign by [Tower Records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tower_Records) titled "___No Music, No Life?___", which began on September 13, 2011.

Continuation of biography here: [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man_with_a_Mission)

___Members:___
- Tokyo Tanaka (トーキョー・タナカ) - vocals, leader
- [Jean-Ken Johnny](https://anilist.co/staff/149135/JeanKen-Johnny) (ジャン・ケン・ジョニー) - guitar, vocals, rap
- [Kamikaze Boy](https://anilist.co/staff/149139/Kamikaze-Boy) (カミカゼ・ボーイ) - bass guitar, backing vocals
- DJ Santa Monica (DJサンタモニカ) - DJ, sampling
- Spear Rib (スペア・リブ) - drums

(Sources: [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man_with_a_Mission) | [ja.wikipedia.org](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAN_WITH_A_MISSION) | [mwamjapan.info](https://www.mwamjapan.info/profiles))

[Website](https://www.milet.jp/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/milet_music) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/milet_music/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/c/miletOfficialYouTubeChannel) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milet) Biography milet is a Japanese pop singer-songwriter under SME Records (2019-). She made her debut on March 6, 2019 with her first EP named inside you EP, with the lead track "inside you" being used as the opening theme for the drama QUEEN. (Source: Wikipedia)
Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/寺尾優一)

Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/). Married to [Momoko Kamiya](https://anilist.co/staff/250361).

Upon enrolling at Osaka University of Arts, Yuuichi Terao, alongside [Takashi Suhara](https://anilist.co/staff/146678/Takashi-Suhara) and others, embarked on the autonomous creation of animated films, even organizing screenings through university circles in the Kanto region. After joining animation production company ufotable in December 2003, Terao, initially aspiring for the production department as a production manager but he was assigned to the newly formed photography department (now the Digital Imaging Department) due to presenting visual materials during his interview. Despite lacking prior photography expertise, he learned from scratch, commencing his career as a compositor. From 2007 onwards, Terao transitioned to the role of "Director of Photography" in notable works such as "The Garden of Sinners." Presently serving as Chief of ufotable's Digital Imaging Department, he oversees photography and CG, contributing significantly to ufotable's works. Beyond photography and CG, Terao actively engages in various roles, including animation, background sections, directing, and storyboarding, even participating in the early stages of background art creation. Noteworthy for his involvement in promotional videos and commercials, Terao gained attention for creating faction-specific commercials for the TV anime [Fate/Zero](https://anilist.co/anime/10087/FateZero/) in 2011. 

His directorial contributions extend to ufotable works' opening sequences and game animations, with a notable debut as a storyboard artist and director in the final episode of the 2019 TV anime [Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba](https://anilist.co/anime/101922/Demon-Slayer-Kimetsu-no-Yaiba/). Terao's multifaceted contributions align with his belief in animation as a collective art form, emphasizing teamwork in production. 

Recognized for his expertise in integrating 3DCG seamlessly with characters and background art, Terao's artistic approach aims for high-quality animation. His "photorealistic" visuals, adopted since 2007, have been praised, contributing to his receipt of the Tokyo Anime Award 2022's "Individual Award".
Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/衛藤功二)

Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).

Born in Hyogo Prefecture, he developed a passion for gaming, leading him to join Studio Sparrow to pursue a career in game animation background art. With little prior experience in drawing, he began honing his skills under the guidance of renowned art director [Masanori Kikuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/156492/Masanori-Kikuchi). He transitioned to Studio Easter in 2003, specializing in background art production, and later served as art director for various anime series including [Speed Grapher](https://anilist.co/anime/198/Speed-Grapher/), [Steins;Gate](https://anilist.co/anime/9253/SteinsGate/) and [Psycho-Pass](https://anilist.co/anime/13601/PSYCHOPASS/).

His involvement with ufotable's theatrical production "The Garden of Sinners" began when a superior at Studio Easter asked for his assistance. Initially planning to contribute only a few cuts, he ended up handling nearly 50 cuts of art in the [Chapter 5](https://anilist.co/anime/4282/the-Garden-of-sinners-Chapter-5-Paradox-Paradigm/). Recognizing his talent, Studio Easter's representative recommended him for the art director role in the [Chapter 6](https://anilist.co/anime/5204/the-Garden-of-sinners-Chapter-6-Fairy-Tale-Oblivion-Recording/) and [Chapter 7](https://anilist.co/anime/5205/the-Garden-of-sinners-Chapter-7-not-nothing-heart-Murder-Speculation-Part-B/).

In 2013, he made a significant career move, transitioning from Studio Easter to ufotable's art department. This shift was prompted by individual requests from ufotable for his involvement in projects like the anime series [Fate/stay night: Unlimited Blade Works](https://anilist.co/anime/19603/Fatestay-night-Unlimited-Blade-Works/). At ufotable, he served as the art director for numerous projects, contributing to the development of the in-house art team alongside ufotable's art department chief, [Kazuo Ebisawa](https://anilist.co/staff/115408/Kazuo-Ebisawa).

On February 9, 2023, he was honored with the [Individual Award in the Art, Color, and Visual Effects](https://animefestival.jp/en/award/aoy/archive/#2023) category at the Tokyo Anime Awards 2023.
Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).
Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Fion0806) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100001583365922) | [Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/0BLHMPWOZ2aTI0ZCCbtZem) | [Apple Music](https://music.apple.com/artist/yuki-kajiura/251013990) | [Deezer](https://www.deezer.com/artist/4663498)

Yuki Kajiura was born in Japan but raised in West Germany for most of her childhood. Her father was a big fan of classical and opera music and always desired for Yuki to play the piano for him. Yuki eventually gained a love for music and a love for the piano. Yuki started out as an SE programmer, but changed to music in 1992. She made her grand debut with a female trio called "[See-Saw](https://anilist.co/staff/104342)."  In the years to come the group released six singles and two albums. 

Yuki then went on to work on her solo career composing for artists and some TV, films, and games, such as _Blood: The Last Vampire_ in 2001, and _Xenosaga II_ and _III_. In 2001, Yuki's claim to fame came with the release of the anime [_NOIR_](https://anilist.co/anime/272). The soundtrack sold 50,000 copies. In 2002, she was brought on to project .hack to write the score to [_.hack//SIGN_](https://anilist.co/anime/48), along with vocalist [Chiaki Ishikawa](https://anilist.co/staff/101059) and New York singer [Emily Bindiger](https://anilist.co/staff/103845). Shortly after Yuki comprised an album of original and complied songs known as Fiction, working again with Emily Bindiger as well as _Xenosaga_ vocalist Deb Lyons.  

Yuki's other well-known works were for [_Mobile Suite Gundam Seed_](https://anilist.co/anime/93), which hit 5th on the Oricon Charts its first week, and selling over 200,000 copies. Yuki has also become known for her work on CLAMP's [_Tsubasa Chronicle_](https://anilist.co/anime/177) series, [movie](https://anilist.co/anime/807), and [OVAs](https://anilist.co/anime/2685). In 2003, she formed the project [FictionJunction](https://anilist.co/staff/103691) in which pairs Yuki's songwriting and composition with different performing vocalists, first as separate solo works and later into a singular group. In 2007, Yuki formed the band [Kalafina](https://anilist.co/staff/101975), with two partners from FictionJunction, Wakana Ootaki and [Keiko Kubota](https://anilist.co/staff/104664), to perform for the anime [_Kara no Kyoukai_](https://anilist.co/anime/2593), further working on several others. Kalafina disbanded in 2018, with their final lineup including Wakana, Keiko, and [Hikaru](https://anilist.co/staff/168857).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/cnago) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/椎名豪)

Masaru Shiina, known professionally as Go Shiina, is a freelance composer and arranger.

He joined Namco in 1997, and was best known during his time with the company for writing music for a number of games in the Tales, Mr. Driller, and God Eater franchises, He gained widespread recognition with his score for Tales of Legendia in 2005. Since then, he has also contributed music for several titles in the Tekken, Ace Combat, and The Idolmaster franchises.

In anime he is most noted for the score of [Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba](https://anilist.co/anime/101922/) together with [Yuki Kajiura](https://anilist.co/staff/100077/).
Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).
Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/寺尾優一)

Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/). Married to [Momoko Kamiya](https://anilist.co/staff/250361).

Upon enrolling at Osaka University of Arts, Yuuichi Terao, alongside [Takashi Suhara](https://anilist.co/staff/146678/Takashi-Suhara) and others, embarked on the autonomous creation of animated films, even organizing screenings through university circles in the Kanto region. Recognized for his expertise in integrating 3DCG seamlessly with characters and background art, Terao's artistic approach aims for high-quality animation. His "photorealistic" visuals, adopted since 2007, have been praised, contributing to his receipt of the Tokyo Anime Award 2022's "Individual Award".

Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/) since 2006.

Graduating from Osaka University of Arts, Suhara, who had a fondness for drawing, assisted in the production of independent animated works by his junior, [Yuichi Terao](https://anilist.co/staff/130063/Yuuichi-Terao), who currently serves as the chief of ufotable's digital imaging department. After completing his university studies, Suhara, drawn to his passion for drawing, learned about Terao joining ufotable and subsequently joined the company in the spring of 2006.
Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).

Affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/) since 2006.
